header.rec_loc: In the ticket office at the TME in Creech-St-Michael.
header.topics: Control systems, MG cars, work ethics, getting things done.
header.activity: A break from the TME working party near Taunton.
header.conv_type: Discussing, Explaining, Inquiring, complaining, anecdote telling

speaker.dialect_rep: I may have a slight Somerset accent
speaker.occupation: retired artist and antique dealer/gallery owner

body.u: well thank you for talking to me today
and erm I know you're a model engine here and you're here on a working party today and you giving your time fifteen minutes to talk to me what would you like to talk about today?
what about your job that the the thing you did before you were erm retired? and erm you're an instrument technician now can you tell me what that entailed?
yes anything from pressure gauges to control systems mostly pneumatic but some of it electronic
what part of the job did you like the best?
really? can you spl stipulate? you liked absolutely all of it?
to the point where I actually left twenty-four years almost to the day that I went in and it felt as though I'd literally been there a week
oh that's a wonderful experience isn't it?
what about the people you worked with?
no I'd sooner not talk about them
there are some I will talk about there are some I won't
yeah? well if you can tell me about some of the characters you work with that would be good
what like like the bare knuckle fighter that used to be there

fought with people like Jack Dempsey who was one of the world champions he was just a character but there were lots of people there were the biggest problem was the fact that I worked day shifts and there were people worked what they called twelve hour shifts and they literally were they used to do two days two nights so you used to see a whole range of different people all the time
and I think that's probably what helped
but some of the people I actually worked with I'd sooner not talk about because I didn't like them very much
and I had to put up with them
yeah mm I well I when I was nursing I had people like that and it was a bit like you
when you're nursing and you think oh I've got to put up with her
and and and and then I think well that's okay cos next week I'm gonna be on a different ward and then
and hopefully I'll get somebody nice
well that's right well this was one particular character I worked with for twenty years in the same room
and I couldn't I I it still rankles with me the amount of the amount of
because of his inability to do the job properly
oh that's really hard isn't it?
and I'm not racist in any way
but he was a West Indian
and he thought he'd learn the job very quickly and he never really did learn the job
so er that and that's why I don't really want to talk about him
steer on to other subjects while you were doing this job that you enjoyed so much for so many years what what what did you do in your leisure time?
ah right and you're keen on cars obviously
I I have been because I had a car I I I still have it it's my MG I love it
I also have a Range Rover which I built rebuilt mechanically
and languishing in the back of the garage is my mother's old Ford
which I've been trying to get at since nineteen eighty
so you've got to make a bit of space to get there have you?
I've gotta stop being bone idle
well you're hardly bone idle being here in a working party are you?
no but er erm as you probably realise my stock answer is no
well the thing is about coming out I mean everyoeveryone here well engineers er all
all work a lot on their own
in er and to come out and do this it's great
that they can get to talk
iit's the company I come for
as much as I don't mind the hard work
no no I'm sure you don't
I mean it's it's good fun
no says you work very hard
if if you're very very hard working
the fact that a lot of the time I did nothing
but when there was work to be done it got done
I mean it was not uncommon for me to go home at night and get called back in at ten o'clock
and work through to five o'clock the next morning
keep asking you if they know you're gonna produce the goods won't they?
there were certain people there who would only ask for me
because they knew the job would be done and it would be done properly
I suppose the work ethic I got came out of what I did when I first left school
you didn't know that did y?
no I didn't so you worked for the police then did you?
collecting blood about three years doing bacteriology
don't you think sometimes when you get your blood tested these days that you can be just under the bar for something?
and and you know you may say thyroid take thyroid did you test for thyroid or er?
I mostly did haematology which was
counting chambers diluted to blood put in your counting chambers put it under a microscope and counted the cells that you could see at a given area
and has that affected you eyesight in later life do you think?
no I don't think it has I've been I think I've been very lucky considering how long I was spent doing that
and when you're doing bacteriology there are times when you sit and look for an hour down the microscope at blank sur plank erm slides
because er hopefully there's nothing on the
yeah but er yeah er but the work ethic erm in that context is very strict
I mean and the work quality has to be good
one mistake and it changes someone's life doesn't it?
yeah so going back to the cars though I had an MG once what sort of make erm I had an MG MG Midget
what sort of car is yours?
an MGB erm and is it is that one with the hard top is it?
oh right and do you go out in that much?
right yeah yeah we we always
we always we always go to that one
yeah I've been there for two years now
have you? yeah we've been well I met and we've been going for twenty years
er I must admit I'm getting a bit fed up with it now
so much you can do it's very limited
every year I go in and you know the tent where they've got the craft people?
there's some people at the back who are in the same place every year
and I sometimes think that they've been there since
in the field since I left the year before
that's right well I mean it's the same I go to quite a few shows
up around erm and and around that area
and because I meet the same people it's like the model engineers it's
erm it it it also leads you out into other things like last Sunday we went to the NEC to the classic
which was quite nice we went up on the coach so we had no worry about driving
and we were dropped off within five minutes of it all and the thing is I'm also a member of a car club
yes well we are in unofficially of the Austin seven club
it's not really a club but
we're just a lot of people who meet and we don't pay a subscription or anything
no but I actually belong to the Ford Sidevalve Owners Club
and I'm the area contact for them
which actually throws up odd things like the other week I went down to to to look at a car to verify that it was what it said it was
so that the chap can get the registration done
the people you meet and the cars you look at
so since I've been retired my life has become much more interesting
cos most of the car work I did before I retired was with a friend of mine who was actually a repairer
and a lot of it was towing cars in for him to repair
erm so erm your car now your B
can you tell me erm have you got much more to do on it? or is it is it sort of all up together maintained and spotless?
er it's all up together but it needs a good coat of paint
erm the ththing about that is the fact that I smashed it up
I'm lucky to be here actually
since then it's had a complete new body shell put on
and it was one of the early heritage shells that came er literally as a body shell all the bolt mark parts
so I've I've actually rebuilt it up from
every nut and bolt and screw
I know it because I put it in there
well we've got something in common then I had an accident in nineteen seventy-eight
well that's ten years before you er
it actually wasn't my fault I was driving to work in the morning
I waited in the drive for erm one of my colleagues and er he hadn't turned up I used give him a lift and er had I gone he was late and had I gone
at the time I should have gone I wouldn't have met the other man on the road
you know but because I waiting for t he was called
I had the accident and he just came towards me overtaking another car
and hit me in the front spun the Mini round and the petrol tank burst into flames and I was trapped in a burning car well

went to hospital erm it's funny actually yyou feel like a bit cheated about having an accident on the way to work in the morning you think well this should be happening at night when I come out of the pub when I've had a few to drink
do you know what I mean? but
I mean that's what you say in those days
when you could have a drink and go to the pub
I certainly don't I don't drink at all now
well I don't either I mean
er would say you're always er even at lunchtime here I'll have a
but that is because the last job I did was strictly er it was classified as category A safety so I used to be
and we had to be sober at nine o'clock
yeah so had to do that
when he was going on the track
every every track he went on you know he had to go on the track at night
he couldn't have a drink you know?
used to say do you want a a drink no can't have a drink
no but my accident wasn't another car
who decided to put a pedestrian reserve in the middle of the road
so you went over it did you?
I I went into it and
and in the back of the car I ca got the photographs of what it looked like there's a railing straight down the centre of
but had I not had a seatbelt on
I would have been thrown out but it actually did affect me physically because the seatbelt wasn't tight and when I had my heart attack a few months ago
I didn't realise it was that
until it wouldn't the pain wouldn't go away and it was getting worse
because I'd suffered this pain on the ster
which was a muscular skeletal muscular thing
yeah having a heart attack is a very weird thing to sort of diagnose because there are so many things it could be like indigestion or
did I stretch up too far to put something down
from the shelf yesterday? you know
yeyeah well yes it's it's just depends on how many symptoms you have
right what were your symptoms then?
anything down at your arm? they always say
and knowing that it was something serious
that told me this but I saw my father had a heart attack you see
he just walked into me and said I don't feel well and I felt his hands and looked at him and said no you go back to bed I'll get the doctor in
this doctor said I think he's only indigestion
it was diagnosed that he'd had a heart attack
oh right what are doing on time here? oh only another two minutes to go
and then you're you've served your sentence
so erm er what might might be interested to know that after I had the accident I erm I was obviously badly burned and my face was burned
er lots of places and erm I went out and I bought an MG Midget and a
yeah er it was only an er a rabbit it was only a rabbit coat
erm but it looked really nice and erm I had to get rid of it when they brought this fur thing in that you couldn't have fur
but once it's in the shop and it's there
and erm I've got treasure I bought my erm MG from a a solicitor friend of mine

and erm er yes and it was so funny my father said we'd better have to looked over by the AA but I wasn't in the AA so they they sent an AA chap to look the car over and he went to erm again this is another 's house

er we went to 's house and erm his mother was very amused that erm my father who was the reverend wanted to look this very small very small MG er er Midget over er because it was in my father's name so they couldn't quite get over it and they thought that it was hilarious
but then of course came back from work and said it was wants it you know that's er but I knew him vaguely at that time but
as a result of that we came got quite good friends and his his then girlfriend we all
erm isn't it funny how these things work out?
I'm you know life goes on doesn't it?
so so erm so when you get your mother's Ford out erm
er and you get onto it can you see that happening in the near future?
I'm trying now I'm trying very hard to get the garage sorted so I can get in there and do something with it and er it it will happen slowly
it's finding the space isn't it?
it's not the space I had the space
I had the garage rebuilt so there was space for it
it's getting the junk out that I've managed to accumulate
so so but with this weather I just don't get in you know
well you can't put things outside temporarily
while you're you're clearing up erm
it is difficult erm maybe you could get one of those little those gazebos that are the same size as this
because they are use they're useful
but I've still got the bungalow to finish
have you done your erm paving yet? you were going to do some
and I'm still getting worms coming up through the grass
I think we've done it okay
